Check this https://github.com/raphw/byte-buddy/issues/322#issuecomment-314840872 for interface.

Use the `hasSuperType()`.

First of all, you are right about altering the return value.

The `InstanceMethodsAroundInterceptor`  and `StaticMethodsAroundInterceptor` both have the capabilities to alter the return value, in both `before` and `after` methods.

* In **after**, override the origin return value.
* In **before**, even mean don't call the origin method.

The risk you mentioned is **true**, but this feature is needed in some plugins:
1. You can check the `JDBCDriverInterceptor#afterMethod`, need to create a `SWConnection` to replace the old one for keeping the connect-url.
1. This Kafka plugin( released in future ), the message is a byte array, which returns by a serializer. In order to keep the trace's cross-process continuation, agent must add a ContextCarrier into the byte array. So we must have the capability to change it.

Although we had took this risk into consideration, so since 3.2, we let the enhanced class implement `EnhancedInstance` interface and a dynamic field to carry extra info. By supporting this, we can avoid to alter return value in most cases, but not all of them, such as kafka plugin.

If you want to contribute or develop a new plugin, please make sure altering return value just is necessary.

And a final thing, sky-walking agent didn't ask the application developers to change their source code manually, but the changing is still be done in runtime. So risks of breaking application always exist, we must do these carefully.
Closing this issue. If you need more explanations, please let me know.

`sysctl -w vm.max_map_count=262144`
Can you post you error message?

```
skywalking-collector_1  | [2017-07-14 03:06:20:226] [INFO] - org.skywalking.apm.collector.worker.storage.EsClient.parseClusterNodes(EsClient.java:62) - es NODES: es-server:9300
skywalking-collector_1  | Exception in thread "main" java.net.UnknownHostException: es-server: Name or service not known
skywalking-collector_1  |       at java.net.Inet4AddressImpl.lookupAllHostAddr(Native Method)
skywalking-collector_1  |       at java.net.InetAddress$2.lookupAllHostAddr(InetAddress.java:928)
skywalking-collector_1  |       at java.net.InetAddress.getAddressesFromNameService(InetAddress.java:1323)
skywalking-collector_1  |       at java.net.InetAddress.getAllByName0(InetAddress.java:1276)
skywalking-collector_1  |       at java.net.InetAddress.getAllByName(InetAddress.java:1192)
skywalking-collector_1  |       at java.net.InetAddress.getAllByName(InetAddress.java:1126)
skywalking-collector_1  |       at java.net.InetAddress.getByName(InetAddress.java:1076)
skywalking-collector_1  |       at org.skywalking.apm.collector.worker.storage.EsClient.boot(EsClient.java:42)
skywalking-collector_1  |       at org.skywalking.apm.collector.worker.CollectorBootStartUp.main(CollectorBootStartUp.java:22)

```

you may be add the following configuration under  the  `es-server` node.
```
 environment:
      - bootstrap.memory_lock=true
      - "ES_JAVA_OPTS=-Xms512m -Xmx512m"
```

The configuration file should be like this after you add the configuration
```
es-server:
    image: elasticsearch:5.3
    command: "-Enode.name=TestNode -Enetwork.host=0.0.0.0 -Ehttp.cors.enabled=true -Ehttp.cors.allow-origin=* -Ethread_pool.bulk.queue_size=1000 -Ecluster.name=CollectorDBCluster"
    environment:
      - bootstrap.memory_lock=true
      - "ES_JAVA_OPTS=-Xms512m -Xmx512m"
    expose:
      - "9200"
      - "9300"
    healthcheck:
      test: ["CMD", "curl", "-f", "http://localhost:9200"]
      interval: 30s
      timeout: 10s
      retries: 5

```

feel embarrassed.
my cloud machine has 992M mem total , 220M free.
How much mem should be needed at least , to support skywalking to work .

After setting ES_JAVA_OPTS=-Xms150m -Xmx150m, skywalking31_es-server_1 exited with code 137.

@aliluyahoho The memory requirement isn't up to us. We use the ElasticSearch as persistence service, and this section of docker-compose is for starting it. So it is up to ElasticSearch. 

220M seems too less....  and if you only have 220M, how can you be sure the elasticsearch won't slow everything down?

If you just want to run test or demonstration, the only option I known is waiting for v3.2. In the next version, the PM ( @pengys5 ) intends to provide a standalone mode, which only use H2-in-memory-mode to run our collector, instead of ElasticSearch for easier usage and less memory requirement.

But if you requirement is running in Product env, either docker-compose or standalone mode are NOT a good choice. I highly recommend to use ElasticSearch Cluster.

Hope these help. Let me know, if you have any more question.

BTW, can you help to **Start** and **Fork** our project for supporting us? Thanks anyway.

@wu-sheng Thx for your question. 
To clear up my confusion, I run collector and web on my mac book. They are work properly. Mem condition show as following image.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6141396/28201137-390f050a-68a2-11e7-86be-bef68285f2d2.png)

I will get my cloud machine configuration upgrade , then try again .

This time is my personal trial. If it makes our team's requirement, we maybe running in product env.

thx a lot.

@aliluyahoho Wait for any feedback. Hope 3.2 will help more people, since we added new features about JVM and service,  and improved performance.

Closing this. Open this or new, if you have something to discuss.

Coverage remained the same at 48.648% when pulling **89427eeaf52849ede0ae9b63376e4b688d79f78e on ascrutae:zhangxin/fix/opeartionId-incorrect** into **76ceb36363283ed2f41fd925ac4ee68d3892f07e on wu-sheng:master**.

## Background story
In the prev edition, traceSegmentId or globalTrace is combined by these parts:
1. 2 bytes, **type**:  T/S (1 char)
1. 26 bytes, **timestamp**, e.g. 1500598177046, (13 chars)
1. 20 bytes, **UUID hashcode**, e.g. 1186075790, (10 chars)
1. 2 - 10 bytes, ** thread id**, most likely between 1 and 99999, (1 - 5 chars)
1. 2 - 22 bytes, ** thread seq**,  between -2147483648 and 2147483647. (1 - 11 chars)

So the ids used 52 - 80 bytes for each one. In `agent -> collector` and `agent -> agent`(cross-process propagation) are same.

cc @hanahmily
cc @liuchang0403

## New ID since 3.2
1. Application instance id, Allocated by collector, @pengys5 . Most likely a short or integer is enough. Let's do the math. First we assume that the backend allocates new id with no reuse mechanism. Even we have 1,000 applications, each one of them has (avg) 50 instances, there cost 50, 000 application ids in every reboot. Reboot the cluster in every two days, (either excellent DevOps team or disaster product), the max application instance id is 18,250,000 ( Far from MAX_INT, 2,147,483,647 ). 
1.  Thread id. Allocated by JVM, in theory, it could be a very big long, but actually, if you application is high performance, most likely you use a thread pool, instead of creating new thread in every time. So in this case, the id will not be too large. most likely between 1 and 30000, ( A short only )
1. timestamp + [0-9999] seq, definitely a long.

So in protobuf, the id is 1 short/int + 1 short + 1 long, which is 12 - 14 bytes. Much less than before.

And in cross-process propagation, mostly HTTP head, we use BASE64 for each part of id. 
1. '#' + 4 chars for short
1. '$' + 8 chars for int
1. 12 chars for long

So the id in BASE64 used 22, 26 or 29 chars.
e.g.
1. (instId)1280 + (threadId)2000 + (timestamp + seq)15006041906190932, base64 is `#AAU=#0Ac=VJpNZepPNQA=`, 22 chars.
1. (instId)111280 + (threadId)2000 + (timestamp + seq)15006041906190932, base64 is `$sLIBAA==#0Ac=FLAq1epPNQA=`, 26 chars. 
1. (instId)15,201,212,800 + (threadId)2000 + (timestamp + seq)15006041906190932, base64 is `gBkQigMAAAA=#0Ac=5N63supPNQA=`, 29 chars.

@hanahmily Thank you for your suggestion. We will add **time-shift-back** recognition mechanism, if we found the **time-shift-back** happened, we switch the timestamp to an integer random, until the time recovery to be safe.
@guorj217 放在Tomcat CLASSPATH相关路径下，会由于不同版本的Tomcat ClassLoader机制不同，可能造成探针被其他classloader加载，造成各种不可预知问题，请知晓。
